message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Bloody discharge from a single duct with no palpable mass or lymphadenopathy suggests an intraductal papilloma. Paget disease of the breast would typically have skin changes, and invasive ductal carcinoma would likely have a palpable mass on examination. Breast lipoma would not cause bloody discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the bloody discharge and dilated duct on ultrasonography, suggest intraductal papilloma. Paget disease of the breast would present with eczematous changes in the nipple-areolar complex, while invasive ductal carcinoma would likely have a palpable mass or lymphadenopathy. Breast lipoma is a benign tumor and would not present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intraductal papilloma, which is a benign tumor of the breast duct. There are no palpable masses or lymphadenopathy, and the mammography did not show any abnormalities, all of which suggest a benign condition. Paget disease would show erythema of the nipple and areola with crusting and scaling, and invasive ductal carcinoma would most likely present as a palpable breast mass. Breast lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose tissue, which usually presents as a painless, soft, and mobile mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a diagnosis of intraductal papilloma, which can cause bloody discharge from the nipple. The absence of breast masses and lymphadenopathy suggests that the cancer has not spread. Breast lipoma is a benign tumor of fat cells, and invasive ductal carcinoma and Paget disease of the breast both involve cancer cells and are more likely to present with palpable masses. Ultrasonography of the breast may reveal intraductal papilloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest an intraductal papilloma, which is a common benign tumor that can cause bloody discharge from the nipple. The absence of palpable masses and axillary lymphadenopathy, as well as the single dilated duct on ultrasonography, further support this diagnosis. Breast lipoma is a benign tumor that does not typically cause nipple discharge. Invasive ductal carcinoma and Paget disease of the breast can both cause nipple discharge, but are typically associated with palpable masses and other imaging findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bloody discharge from a single nipple and a single dilated duct on breast ultrasound is consistent with the diagnosis of intraductal papilloma. Breast lipoma presents as a well-circumscribed mass, invasive ductal carcinoma may present with non-bloody discharge and a palpable mass, and Paget disease usually presents with a scaly lesion on the nipple.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest a possible ductal discharge, and the ultrasonography showing a single dilated duct points to intraductal papilloma. Paget disease of the breast and invasive ductal carcinoma usually present with nipple or breast mass, while breast lipoma is a rare cause of breast discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptom of bloody discharge from a single duct with no palpable masses suggests the most likely diagnosis is intraductal papilloma. Paget disease of the breast may present with nipple discharge and skin changes, but there is no mention of skin changes in the question. Invasive ductal carcinoma is a type of breast cancer and is less likely to present with isolated bloody nipple discharge. Breast lipoma is a benign tumor and is not associated with nipple discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bloody discharge from a single dilated breast duct suggests intraductal papilloma, which is the most likely diagnosis. Invasive ductal carcinoma usually presents as a palpable breast mass, while Paget disease of the breast presents with eczematous changes to the nipple and areola. Breast lipoma would not cause bloody nipple discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of bloody discharge from a single duct along with a single dilated duct on ultrasonography suggests intraductal papilloma as the most likely diagnosis. Paget disease would present with erythema, scaling, and crusting of the nipple and areola. Invasive ductal carcinoma may present as bloody discharge but would likely also have a palpable mass and axillary lymphadenopathy. Breast lipoma is a benign tumor that would not present with bloody discharge.
